title: Womens' Heights: Z-score Equation When Given the Percentile
question_text:
Women's heights are approximately normally distributed with a mean of $63.6\text{ inches}$ and a standard deviation of $2.5\text{ inches}$.
Which of the following equations can be used to find the height $x$ in which $18\%$ of the heights fall above?
solution:
If $x$ is an observation from a normal distribution with a known mean and standard deviation, the z-score of $x$ is:

$$z=\dfrac { \text{x-mean }}{ \text{standard deviation} } $$

Using process of elimination, we can eliminate Choices 'A' and 'D' as $63.6$ and $x$ are incorrectly placed in the numerator.

Now we need to find the z-score for $82\%$ either using Table A or a graphing calculator. The reason for $82\%$ and not $18\%$ is we are looking for the cutoff for the top$18\%$ which equivalent to the bottom $82\%$. Table A and the graphing calculator takes the bottom area(cumulative area) also known as the area to the left.

Using table A: Look in the middle of the chart look for an entry closest to $0.82$. It is $0.8212$. This is the entry corresponding to z = $0.92$.

Area represents the area to the left. In this case, we want the cutoff for the bottom $82\%$ of heights so the area would be $0.82$.

The mean, $\mu $, is represented by $0$ and the standard deviation,$\sigma$, is represented by $1$ because we have standardized the variable $x$.

Choice 'B' is eliminated as the z-score is $0.92$ and not $-0.92$.

Choice 'C' is incorrect as the z-score for the top $18 \%$ was never found.
